block.p: MONGOLIA: FORMER COMMUNISTS WIN The country's former Communist rulers won a landslide victory in elections on Sunday and vowed to push ahead with economic reforms while doing more to combat the social costs of the painful 10-year transition from Soviet satellite to a free market. Unofficial results showed the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party won 72 out of the 76 open parliamentary seats. The party had ruled Mongolia from the 1920's until 1996, when it was ousted by a democratic coalition.

INDIA: SRI LANKA PEACE PLAN India said it had devised a package to end fighting in Sri Lanka and was ready to take part in talks between the Sri Lankan government and Tamil rebels. Junior Foreign Minister Ajit Panja said India favored a united Sri Lanka but did not disclose details of the proposed package. Officials said Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, would send a special envoy to India this week.

JAPAN: U.S. MARINE ARRESTED IN OKINAWA The police arrested a United States marine for allegedly molesting a 14-year-old girl, threatening to stir up already tense relations between local residents and American forces weeks before a meeting of the world's leading industrialized economies. The 19-year-old marine, accused of breaking into a home and molesting the girl in her room, denied the charge.

COLOMBIA: TRUCE TALKS Government officials and leaders of the country's main guerrilla movement, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, met in Los Pozos, 435 miles south of the capital, to exchange proposals aimed at bringing an end to decades of fighting. Their plans for an eventual cease-fire, however, were expected to contrast sharply.

SWITZERLAND: MOSSAD AGENT ADMITS SPYING An Israeli secret service agent testified that he took part in a bungled wiretapping two years ago in the Swiss capital, Bern. The agent, using an alias for the trial, is accused of having tried to bug the apartment of a suspected Hezbollah sympathizer.

SLOVAKIA: PRESIDENT'S POWERS TRANSFERRED Prime Minister Mikulas Dzurinda and the Parliament speaker, Jozef Migas, have assumed the powers of President Rudolf Schuster, 66, who remains hospitalized in Austria after emergency abdominal surgery.

LITHUANIA: NAZI CRIMES TRIAL HALTED A court called an indefinite halt to the country's first Nazi-era war crimes trial, citing the poor health of 93-year-old defendant, Aleksandras Lileikis. Mr. Lileikis, a former American citizen stripped of his passport, has denied charges that he turned over Jews to Nazi executioners during the German occupation of Lithuania.

NORTHERN IRELAND: VIOLENCE OVER MARCH Dozens of Protestant militants attacked police in Drumcree, Northern Ireland, with bricks and bottles after the province's Parades Commission barred members of the Protestant Orange Order from parading after services this Sunday. The commission said they could march at a future date if they agreed to speak with Catholic residents who object to the march coming through their neighborhood.

ZIMBABWE: WHITE FARMERS' BID Zimbabwe's white farmers union said more than 200 white-owned farms would be offered for immediate sale to President Robert Mugabe's government for black resettlement. The offer came on the last day for commercial farmers to object to Mr. Mugabe's plan to seize 804 white-owned farms for redistribution to landless peasants.

SOUTH AFRICA: DISPUTE ON CAUSE OF AIDS SWIRLS President Thabo Mbeki's administration fired back at 5,000 scientists who signed a letter affirming H.I.V. as the cause of AIDS, saying their declaration was a ''waste of time'' and a distraction days before the International AIDS Conference opens in the South African city of Durban. Mr. Mbeki, whose country has more H.I.V.-positive people than any other, has angered many AIDS researchers and activists by his position.

EGYPT: PROTESTS OVER ARRESTS Human rights groups called for the release of Saad Eddin Ibrahim, an American-Egyptian sociologist who was arrested Friday night. Mr. Ibrahim, a professor at the American University in Cairo and head of an Egyptian think tank, said he was charged with preparing a documentary about elections that harms Egypt's image and receiving foreign funds without government permission.

ISRAEL: MILITARY EXEMPTION BILL After long debate, Parliament passed a preliminary bill that would legalize a practice of granting draft exemptions for ultra-Orthodox seminary students. The bill, sponsored by Prime Minister Ehud Barak, would change the present system, which keeps some religious men in school and out of the workforce well into middle age to keep their exemptions. It would allow religious students who left school to serve four months in a special unit in place of three years of mandatory service.

FIJI: CIVILIAN GOVERNMENT Defying the gunmen holding the deposed government hostage, the military leader appointed a temporary civilian government but said he would retain power until the captives are freed. Commodore Frank Bainimarama, who took power 10 days after rebels stormed Parliament on May 19 and seized top officials, appointed the new government without consulting the gunmen, who demanded a role.
